newsitem.title: MOROCCO: Morocco's Treasury cuts rate on T-bill issues.
newsitem.headline: Morocco's Treasury cuts rate on T-bill issues.

text.p: Morocco's Treasury has cut by half a point to between 8.5 percent and 9.5 percent interest rates on short and medium term Treasury bills, a central bank official said on Monday.
"The decision of discounting Treasury bills by half a point to between 8.5 and 9.5 percent was effective from March 19, 1997," the official at Bank al-Maghrib (central bank) said.
It raised 676.50 million dirhams ($72 million) from its weekly treasury bill auction on Wednesday, the bank said.
"The treasury cut its interest rates because the inflation rate was too low...Since the end of 1996 the money market was heading towards a declining trend," a Casablanca-based banker said.
According to the Finance Ministry, Morocco's inflation dropped to 3.0 percent in 1996 from 6.1 percent in the previous year.
The decision coincided with the finance ministry announcement on Monday of a discounted public T-bond issue on the Casablanca stock exchange at between 8.5 and 9.5 percent interest rate.
Subscription will be closed on March 28, 1997, the spokesman said.
The Treasury bonds called "Emprunt National" are listed on the stock exchange as part of the state domestic debt oriented to small investors and will be negotiable on the market from March 31, 1997.

"Eligible auction participants including banks and insurance firms may find these rates less attractive...And allocate more funds to the stock market which provides higher return yields," Sofia Echihabi, a market analyst at Upline Securities stockbroker said.
It also took place with Morocco's commercial banks decision to cut interest rates by two points on medium and long term investment loans to small and medium-sized firms, a banker said.
King Hassan urged banks and the finance ministry, in his throne speech on March 3, to cut interest rates on loans particularly to small and medium-sized firms.
Total domestic borrowing more than doubled in 1995 to 13 billion dirhams from 5.2 billion dirhams in 1994, Bank al-Maghrib central bank said in its latest report.
A Casablanca-based stockbroker estimates at 19 billion dirhams the total amount of the Treasury bonds issues in 1996.
